data_findings.finding: This is a 2D packing optimization problem: pack 1-200 Christmas trees into smallest square bounding boxes. Score = sum(s_n^2/n) for n=1 to 200. Lower is better. Target: 68.922808. Best public kernel: 71.78.
Tree shape: 15-vertex polygon with trunk (0.15x0.2), 3 tiers (base 0.7, mid 0.4, top 0.25), tip at y=0.8. Position defined by (x,y) at trunk top center and rotation angle (deg).
Key technique: Ensemble approach - collect best solutions per N from multiple sources (CSV files, kernels), then optimize further. This is the foundation of all top solutions.

Simulated Annealing (SA) with translations: C++ implementation with OpenMP parallelization. Key params: iterations (15000-50000), restarts (5-8), temperature schedule (1.0 to 0.000005). Includes local search and fractional translation refinement.
Fractional translation: Fine-grained optimization using tiny steps (0.001 to 0.00001) in 8 directions to nudge trees into tighter positions without overlap. Critical for final score improvement.

BackPacking strategy: Start from n=200 and iterate backward to n=1. When a configuration at n trees performs poorly, copy the best configuration found so far and drop extra trees. Propagates successful patterns.

Greedy construction: Place trees one by one, starting far from center and moving inward until collision, then backing up. Use weighted angle distribution (abs(sin(2*angle))) to favor diagonal placements for better corner filling.
